qa_pairs.question: What role did the Yahoo Toolbar play in addressing the issues caused by Claria's software, and what was its impact on the relationship between Yahoo and Claria?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The Yahoo Toolbar was developed to allow users to remove adware and spyware from their systems, which addressed the issues caused by Claria's software interfering with Yahoo's services. The introduction of the Yahoo Toolbar likely strained the relationship between Yahoo and Claria, as it disrupted the operation of Claria's software and may have created tensions between the two companies.<cite>[S69]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S59] ## Adware partnership

In April 2003, Overture announced a three-year partnership with Gator Corporation, (now Claria Corporation) an adware company. [S60] Under the partnership, Gator's software monitored a web-user's activity on web sites and search engines (even sites such as Google that are not affiliated with Overture) and grabbed search keywords. [S61] These keywords were submitted to the Overture search engine. [S62] As a result, advertisers who paid for listings in Overture found their products advertised through Gator's Search Scout software, even if they wanted nothing to do with Gator. [S63] Overture faced a great deal of criticism for entering into this partnership. [S64] When Yahoo acquired Overture, the Claria software impaired the operation of Yahoo's services. [S65] For example, when a user with a Claria application installed used Yahoo Search, they received a standard set of Yahoo results with sponsored listings at the top supplied by Overture. [S66] The user would then receive a full-screen pop-under window from Search Scout. [S67] Since Search Scout uses Overture's paid listings as well, Claria's window has exactly the same listings as the Yahoo search results. [S68] Subsequently, Yahoo came out with the *Yahoo Toolbar*, which allows users to remove adware and spyware from their system. [S69] The toolbar affected the operation of Claria's software and may have put stress on the relationship between the two companies.

qa_pairs.question: Why did the partnership between Overture and Gator lead to unintended ad placements for advertisers, and how did this affect user experience?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The partnership between Overture and Gator led to unintended ad placements because Gator's software monitored web activity and submitted search keywords to Overture, causing advertisers' listings to appear through Gator's Search Scout software without their consent.<cite>[S61][S62][S63]</cite></statement> <statement>This affected user experience by introducing intrusive full-screen pop-under windows from Search Scout alongside search results, creating redundancy and annoyance for users. For example, Yahoo users with Claria software encountered standardized Yahoo results followed by Search Scout pop-ups using the same Overture-paid listings, disrupting seamless navigation.<cite>[S65][S66][S67][S68]</cite></statement>

qa_pairs.question: How did the Claria software's use of Overture's paid listings create a conflict with Yahoo's search results, and what was the outcome of this overlap?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The Claria software, through its partnership with Overture, monitored users' web activity and submitted search keywords to Overture's search engine, causing Overture's paid listings to appear via Claria's Search Scout software even for advertisers unrelated to Claria. This created a conflict as Claria's pop-under windows displayed the same sponsored results as Yahoo's search pages, undermining Yahoo's control over its own search interface.<cite>[S60][S61][S62][S63][S65][S66][S68]</cite></statement> <statement>The overlap led Yahoo to release the Yahoo Toolbar to remove adware like Claria, disrupting Claria's operations and straining the relationship between the companies. This outcome highlighted the tension between Yahoo's search integrity and Claria's adware-driven distribution of Overture's paid listings.<cite>[S69]</cite></statement>

qa_pairs.question: What were the key reasons behind Yahoo's acquisition of Overture, and how did this acquisition influence the development of Yahoo's advertising platforms, including the transition from Panama to Gemini?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Yahoo's acquisition of Overture was driven by the need to strengthen its position in the search advertising market, which was dominated by Google. By acquiring Overture, Yahoo inherited a proven search advertising business and its innovative pay-for-placement model, which allowed Yahoo to compete more effectively in this lucrative sector.<cite>[S26][S35]</cite></statement> <statement>The acquisition of Overture provided Yahoo with advanced technologies and a sophisticated algorithm for managing search ads, which addressed the limitations of its earlier simplistic approach. This allowed Yahoo to transition from its initial model, which ranked ads solely by bid price, to a more competitive system that incorporated click-through rates, improving both revenue and user experience.<cite>[S36][S38][S39]</cite></statement> <statement>The development of Yahoo's advertising platforms, including the transition from Panama to Gemini, was influenced by the integration of Overture's expertise. Panama, launched in 2007, aimed to close the gap with Google by offering advertisers tools for campaign management and bid optimization, building on Overture's foundational work.<cite>[S30][S36][S43]</cite></statement> <statement>Under Marissa Mayer's leadership, Yahoo further evolved its advertising capabilities with the Gemini platform, which introduced native advertising and a "quality index" to enhance ad relevance and performance. This represented a strategic shift toward more integrated and data-driven advertising solutions, leveraging the technological and operational foundations established through the Overture acquisition.<cite>[S46][S47]</cite></statement> <statement>The Overture acquisition also provided Yahoo with critical intellectual property, including patents related to pay-for-placement search models. This legal and technological edge helped Yahoo solidify its advertising infrastructure, enabling subsequent innovations like Gemini while defending against competitive challenges.<cite>[S48][S53]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S30] **Panama** was an online advertising platform created by Yahoo!, launched on 5 February 2007. [S31] Panama was Yahoo's effort to close the wide gap with Google in the race for search advertising dollars, a fast-growing business then dominated by Google, which is now also dominated by Google. [S32] Customers with accounts already on Yahoo! [S33] were transferred to the new system over the following few months. [S34] Yahoo! [S35] inherited the search advertising business when it purchased Overture (previously named Goto.com). [S36] Until Panama, Yahoo! [S37] search continued to operate the original simplistic algorithm which ranked text ads according to how much advertisers bid for the keyword searched by the user. [S38] Meanwhile, Google operates under a more sophisticated model, which ranks paid ads on the basis of bid price as well as prior click-through rates. [S39] This improvement generally produces higher click through rates (hence higher revenues) for the search engine.ᶜⁱᵗᵃᵗⁱᵒⁿ ⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ This also allowed Yahoo to control the pricing of ad auctions rather than having the auctions operate at market value. [S40] For example, an ambulance-chasing attorney bidding for the keywords "back pain" would likely get a lower clickthrough rate than the keyword "physiotherapist", regardless of what the two parties bid per click. [S41] An algorithm that eventually de-prioritizes the attorney's ad is better for the search engine (in terms of revenue produced) and the user (more relevant ads). [S42] Key players in the Panama project were Brian Acton, David Henke & Qi Lu. [S43] #### Features

The platform provided advertisers with a digital dashboard where they can manage their marketing campaigns, aim ads geographically, and test their effectiveness. [S44] It included interactive tools that suggest to advertisers what to bid based on their budget and the number of users they want to attract. [S45] ### Yahoo Gemini

During the tenure of Marissa Mayer as Yahoo's CEO she started a new advertising platform project under the name Gemini. [S46] The goal was to build a native advertising solution, where the ads take on the format of the content they accompany. [S47] The so-called "quality index" gave advertisers a sense of how the system would rank an ad along with sophisticated analytical tools that gave advertisers insights on why certain campaigns had been effective.ᶜⁱᵗᵃᵗⁱᵒⁿ ⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ


## Patent litigation

In May 1999, GoTo filed a patent application titled "System and method for influencing a position on a search result list generated by a computer network search engine", which was granted as in July 2001. [S48] A related patent has also been granted in Australia and other patent applications remain pending. [S49] Prior to its acquisition by Yahoo, Overture initiated infringement proceedings under this patent against FindWhat.com in January 2002 and Google in April 2002. [S50] The lawsuit against Google related to its AdWords service. [S51] In February 2002, Google introduced a service called AdWords Select that allowed marketers to bid for higher placement in marked sections - a tactic that had some similarities to Overture's search-listing auctions. [S52] Following Yahoo's acquisition of Overture, the lawsuit was settled with Google agreeing to issue 2.7 million shares of common stock to Yahoo in exchange for a perpetual license. [S53] ## Trademark issues

In 2013, the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals held in Lens.com, Inc. [S54] v. [S55] 1-800 Contacts, Inc. [S56] that online contact lens seller Lens.com did not commit trademark infringement when it purchased Yahoo and Google AdWords search advertisements using competitor 1-800 Contacts' federally registered 1800 CONTACTS trademark as a keyword. [S57] In August 2016, the Federal Trade Commission filed an administrative complaint against 1-800 Contacts alleging, among other things, that its search advertising trademark enforcement practices have unreasonably restrained competition in violation of the FTC Act. [S58] 1-800 Contacts has denied all wrongdoing and was scheduled to appear before an FTC administrative law judge in April 2017.

[S1] Yahoo Native


# Yahoo Native



**Yahoo! [S2] Native** (formerly known as **Yahoo! [S3] Advertising**, **Yahoo! [S4] Search Marketing** and **Yahoo! [S5] Gemini**) is a native "Pay per click" Internet advertising service provided by Yahoo. [S6] Yahoo began offering this service after acquiring **Overture Services, Inc.** The current offering of Yahoo Native launched in 2014 as Yahoo! [S7] Gemini. [S8] It handles advertising for both Yahoo and AOL properties, as well as other media outlets. [S9] ## History


### GoTo and Overture

GoTo (not to be confused with Go.com or Go2Net) was an Idealab spin off and was the first company to successfully provide a pay-for-placement search service. [S10] It started off with the purchase of World Wide Web Worm (WWWW), one of the oldest search engines. [S11] GoTo is considered to have been an influential pioneer of paid search. [S12] In February 1998, GoTo offered advertisers the option of bidding on how much they would be willing to pay to appear at the top of results in response to specific searches. [S13] The bid amount was paid by the advertiser to GoTo every time a searcher clicked on a link to the advertiser's website. [S14] By July 1998, advertisers were paying anything up to a dollar per click. [S15] In June 1999, GoTo launched a tool set *direct traffic centre* (dtc) to enable advertisers access to keywords and real time bidding. [S16] GoTo's business model was based on the idea that its paid listings would make it more relevant than other services, especially for general searches, and web sites that pay more are probably better sites. [S17] A similar service had been offered by Open Text in 1996, but this precipitated outcries and bad publicity because searchers at the time did not want the search process more commercialized. [S18] In contrast, GoTo's pay-for-placement model was very successful. [S19] Commenters theorized that the Internet had matured in the intervening two years, and this type of economic models were more acceptable since the web was no longer just a place for academic research, but also a place for buying products. [S20] GoTo founder Bill Gross speculated at the launch that GoTo would succeed because, as a relatively new service, it had no reputation to taint with paid listings, unlike Open Text. [S21] On October 8, 2001, GoTo renamed itself Overture Services, Inc. [S22] GoTo's chief operating officer Jaynie Studenmund, mother of fallen U.S. [S23] soldier Scott Studenmund, said, "We also felt it was a sophisticated enough name, in case our products expand."

Through partnerships, Overture enabled portals such as MSN and Yahoo to monetize the hundreds of millions of web searches made each day on their sites. [S24] Indeed, these partnerships proved highly lucrative, and in a period otherwise marked by dot-com failures, Overture became a substantial profit driver for portals like Yahoo

This success enabled Overture to acquire web sites such as AltaVista and AlltheWeb. [S25] ### Acquisition of Overture by Yahoo! [S26] On October 7, 2003, Overture was acquired by its biggest customer, Yahoo!, for $1.63 billion. [S27] The old brand name of Overture was phased out as Yahoo rebranded many of its products under the Yahoo name. [S28] The exception to this was in Japan and Korea where the local businesses continued to use the Overture brand. [S29] ### Panama

qa_pairs.question: How did the Tenth Circuit Court's ruling in Lens.com, Inc. v. 1-800 Contacts, Inc. reflect broader implications for trademark enforcement in search advertising, and what was the subsequent FTC action?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The Tenth Circuit Court's ruling in *Lens.com, Inc. v. 1-800 Contacts, Inc.* held that Lens.com did not commit trademark infringement by using 1-800 Contacts' federally registered trademark "1800 CONTACTS" as a keyword in search advertisements. This decision highlighted that trademark owners cannot necessarily prevent competitors from using their trademarks as keywords in search ads, reflecting a broader implication that trademark enforcement in search advertising may be limited unless specific conditions (e.g., consumer confusion) are met.<cite>[S57]</cite></statement><statement>Following the ruling, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) filed an administrative complaint against 1-800 Contacts in August 2016, alleging that its trademark enforcement practices unreasonably restrained competition in violation of the FTC Act. The FTC's action targeted 1-800 Contacts' efforts to block competitors from using its trademark as a keyword, suggesting concerns about anti-competitive behavior despite the court's narrow ruling on infringement.<cite>[S58]</cite></statement>

Passage 1:
[S30] **Panama** was an online advertising platform created by Yahoo!, launched on 5 February 2007. [S31] Panama was Yahoo's effort to close the wide gap with Google in the race for search advertising dollars, a fast-growing business then dominated by Google, which is now also dominated by Google. [S32] Customers with accounts already on Yahoo! [S33] were transferred to the new system over the following few months. [S34] Yahoo! [S35] inherited the search advertising business when it purchased Overture (previously named Goto.com). [S36] Until Panama, Yahoo! [S37] search continued to operate the original simplistic algorithm which ranked text ads according to how much advertisers bid for the keyword searched by the user. [S38] Meanwhile, Google operates under a more sophisticated model, which ranks paid ads on the basis of bid price as well as prior click-through rates. [S39] This improvement generally produces higher click through rates (hence higher revenues) for the search engine.ᶜⁱᵗᵃᵗⁱᵒⁿ ⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ This also allowed Yahoo to control the pricing of ad auctions rather than having the auctions operate at market value. [S40] For example, an ambulance-chasing attorney bidding for the keywords "back pain" would likely get a lower clickthrough rate than the keyword "physiotherapist", regardless of what the two parties bid per click. [S41] An algorithm that eventually de-prioritizes the attorney's ad is better for the search engine (in terms of revenue produced) and the user (more relevant ads). [S42] Key players in the Panama project were Brian Acton, David Henke & Qi Lu. [S43] #### Features

The platform provided advertisers with a digital dashboard where they can manage their marketing campaigns, aim ads geographically, and test their effectiveness. [S44] It included interactive tools that suggest to advertisers what to bid based on their budget and the number of users they want to attract. [S45] ### Yahoo Gemini

During the tenure of Marissa Mayer as Yahoo's CEO she started a new advertising platform project under the name Gemini. [S46] The goal was to build a native advertising solution, where the ads take on the format of the content they accompany. [S47] The so-called "quality index" gave advertisers a sense of how the system would rank an ad along with sophisticated analytical tools that gave advertisers insights on why certain campaigns had been effective.ᶜⁱᵗᵃᵗⁱᵒⁿ ⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ


## Patent litigation

In May 1999, GoTo filed a patent application titled "System and method for influencing a position on a search result list generated by a computer network search engine", which was granted as in July 2001. [S48] A related patent has also been granted in Australia and other patent applications remain pending. [S49] Prior to its acquisition by Yahoo, Overture initiated infringement proceedings under this patent against FindWhat.com in January 2002 and Google in April 2002. [S50] The lawsuit against Google related to its AdWords service. [S51] In February 2002, Google introduced a service called AdWords Select that allowed marketers to bid for higher placement in marked sections - a tactic that had some similarities to Overture's search-listing auctions. [S52] Following Yahoo's acquisition of Overture, the lawsuit was settled with Google agreeing to issue 2.7 million shares of common stock to Yahoo in exchange for a perpetual license. [S53] ## Trademark issues

In 2013, the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals held in Lens.com, Inc. [S54] v. [S55] 1-800 Contacts, Inc. [S56] that online contact lens seller Lens.com did not commit trademark infringement when it purchased Yahoo and Google AdWords search advertisements using competitor 1-800 Contacts' federally registered 1800 CONTACTS trademark as a keyword. [S57] In August 2016, the Federal Trade Commission filed an administrative complaint against 1-800 Contacts alleging, among other things, that its search advertising trademark enforcement practices have unreasonably restrained competition in violation of the FTC Act. [S58] 1-800 Contacts has denied all wrongdoing and was scheduled to appear before an FTC administrative law judge in April 2017.

# Yahoo Native



**Yahoo! [S2] Native** (formerly known as **Yahoo! [S3] Advertising**, **Yahoo! [S4] Search Marketing** and **Yahoo! [S5] Gemini**) is a native "Pay per click" Internet advertising service provided by Yahoo. [S6] Yahoo began offering this service after acquiring **Overture Services, Inc.** The current offering of Yahoo Native launched in 2014 as Yahoo! [S7] Gemini. [S8] It handles advertising for both Yahoo and AOL properties, as well as other media outlets. [S9] ## History


### GoTo and Overture

GoTo (not to be confused with Go.com or Go2Net) was an Idealab spin off and was the first company to successfully provide a pay-for-placement search service. [S10] It started off with the purchase of World Wide Web Worm (WWWW), one of the oldest search engines. [S11] GoTo is considered to have been an influential pioneer of paid search. [S12] In February 1998, GoTo offered advertisers the option of bidding on how much they would be willing to pay to appear at the top of results in response to specific searches. [S13] The bid amount was paid by the advertiser to GoTo every time a searcher clicked on a link to the advertiser's website. [S14] By July 1998, advertisers were paying anything up to a dollar per click. [S15] In June 1999, GoTo launched a tool set *direct traffic centre* (dtc) to enable advertisers access to keywords and real time bidding. [S16] GoTo's business model was based on the idea that its paid listings would make it more relevant than other services, especially for general searches, and web sites that pay more are probably better sites. [S17] A similar service had been offered by Open Text in 1996, but this precipitated outcries and bad publicity because searchers at the time did not want the search process more commercialized. [S18] In contrast, GoTo's pay-for-placement model was very successful. [S19] Commenters theorized that the Internet had matured in the intervening two years, and this type of economic models were more acceptable since the web was no longer just a place for academic research, but also a place for buying products. [S20] GoTo founder Bill Gross speculated at the launch that GoTo would succeed because, as a relatively new service, it had no reputation to taint with paid listings, unlike Open Text. [S21] On October 8, 2001, GoTo renamed itself Overture Services, Inc. [S22] GoTo's chief operating officer Jaynie Studenmund, mother of fallen U.S. [S23] soldier Scott Studenmund, said, "We also felt it was a sophisticated enough name, in case our products expand."

Through partnerships, Overture enabled portals such as MSN and Yahoo to monetize the hundreds of millions of web searches made each day on their sites. [S24] Indeed, these partnerships proved highly lucrative, and in a period otherwise marked by dot-com failures, Overture became a substantial profit driver for portals like Yahoo

This success enabled Overture to acquire web sites such as AltaVista and AlltheWeb. [S25] ### Acquisition of Overture by Yahoo! [S26] On October 7, 2003, Overture was acquired by its biggest customer, Yahoo!, for $1.63 billion. [S27] The old brand name of Overture was phased out as Yahoo rebranded many of its products under the Yahoo name. [S28] The exception to this was in Japan and Korea where the local businesses continued to use the Overture brand. [S29] ### Panama

qa_pairs.question: What were the consequences of Overture's partnership with Gator Corporation, and how did it impact Yahoo's services after its acquisition?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The partnership between Overture and Gator Corporation led to significant criticism for Overture due to the invasive nature of Gator's adware, which monitored user activity and submitted search keywords to Overture's engine, even for unaffiliated sites like Google.<cite>[S60][S61][S63]</cite></statement> <statement>After Yahoo acquired Overture, Claria's (formerly Gator) software impaired Yahoo's services, causing conflicts such as full-screen pop-under windows from Search Scout that duplicated Overture's paid listings, disrupting the user experience.<cite>[S64][S65][S67][S68]</cite></statement> <statement>Yahoo addressed the issue by releasing the *Yahoo Toolbar*, which allowed users to remove adware and spyware, potentially straining the relationship between Yahoo and Claria.<cite>[S69]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S59] ## Adware partnership

In April 2003, Overture announced a three-year partnership with Gator Corporation, (now Claria Corporation) an adware company. [S60] Under the partnership, Gator's software monitored a web-user's activity on web sites and search engines (even sites such as Google that are not affiliated with Overture) and grabbed search keywords. [S61] These keywords were submitted to the Overture search engine. [S62] As a result, advertisers who paid for listings in Overture found their products advertised through Gator's Search Scout software, even if they wanted nothing to do with Gator. [S63] Overture faced a great deal of criticism for entering into this partnership. [S64] When Yahoo acquired Overture, the Claria software impaired the operation of Yahoo's services. [S65] For example, when a user with a Claria application installed used Yahoo Search, they received a standard set of Yahoo results with sponsored listings at the top supplied by Overture. [S66] The user would then receive a full-screen pop-under window from Search Scout. [S67] Since Search Scout uses Overture's paid listings as well, Claria's window has exactly the same listings as the Yahoo search results. [S68] Subsequently, Yahoo came out with the *Yahoo Toolbar*, which allows users to remove adware and spyware from their system. [S69] The toolbar affected the operation of Claria's software and may have put stress on the relationship between the two companies.

qa_pairs.question: How did the integration of Gator's software with Yahoo Search create a conflict for users and advertisers?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The integration of Gator's software with Yahoo Search created a conflict for users by displaying duplicate sponsored listings. When users with Claria applications used Yahoo Search, they received standard Yahoo results alongside Overture-sponsored listings, followed by a full-screen pop-under window from Search Scout that mirrored the same Overture-paid listings, causing confusion and disruption.<cite>[S65][S66][S67][S68]</cite></statement> <statement>For advertisers, the conflict arose because Gator's software submitted search keywords to Overture, leading to their ads appearing through Gator's Search Scout even if they had no affiliation with Gator, undermining their control over ad placement.<cite>[S62][S63]</cite></statement>
